answers.q: what is sodium nitrate used for
answers.a: In foods, sodium nitrate (E251) is used as a preservative and color-fixative in cured meats and some cheeses, where it slowly converts to nitrite to help inhibit harmful bacteria and maintain the characteristic pink color.

answers.q: is sodium nitrate bad for you
answers.a: At permitted food levels it's considered safe; regulators set an acceptable daily intake of 3.7 mg nitrate ion per kg body weight per day. High intakes from processed meats are linked to increased colorectal cancer risk, so levels are strictly controlled and often paired with ascorbate to limit nitrosamines.

answers.q: is sodium nitrate soluble in water
answers.a: Yes—it's highly water-soluble (about 90 g per 100 g water around room temperature), with solubility increasing as temperature rises.

answers.q: how to get sodium nitrate nms
answers.a: That refers to the video game No Man’s Sky and is outside the scope of food additives; in foods, sodium nitrate is a curing preservative mainly used in dry-cured meats.
Yes; it is very soluble in water and only sparingly soluble in alcohols, while being essentially insoluble in nonpolar solvents.
